rename.from: Add windows file properties (version info and Icon resources)
rename.to: Add windows file properties (version info and icon resources)

body:
Perhaps something like this:
- Add execution of `go get github.com/josephspurrier/goversioninfo` to rclone's `Makefile`, to get the command line utility in place.
- Port the "syso-file" related code from Syncthing's [build.go](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/master/build.go) into a separate .go file in bin folder of rclone repo.
- Execute the new .go file from the makefile with `go run`, to generate a .syso file.
- Continue with the existing build steps, the go build will automatically pick up the .syso file.

> I know I can execute `rclone version`, but then I need to perform string parsing and also I need to run a process instead of just accessing file properties.

You can also execute `rclone version --check` to see whether your version is up to date with the latest version.

> Solution seems to be based on executing a command line utility, [GoVersionInfo](https://github.com/josephspurrier/goversioninfo), during the build process.

That looks like a good tool :-)
 
> I could try to implement this myself, if you agree it is a good idea, but I am not proficient in go so may be needing some pointers along the way (for instance I am not sure if this introduces some changes to how the build process must be performed).

Yes if you'd like to have a go - that would be fantastic.

The production build is kicked off here

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/fb61ed8506e68db0ea19c62a08daa9cdee59dda5/bin/cross-compile.go#L172

So you'd want to run the goversioninfo tool just once, probably in this function

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/fb61ed8506e68db0ea19c62a08daa9cdee59dda5/bin/cross-compile.go#L226

You can use the runEnv command to run a binary

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/fb61ed8506e68db0ea19c62a08daa9cdee59dda5/bin/cross-compile.go#L72

You can add build dependencies to rclone by adding them here - so you'd add `goversioninfo` here.

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/fb61ed8506e68db0ea19c62a08daa9cdee59dda5/Makefile#L85-L87

The logos for rclone are in the top level graphics directory - I'd expect you'd need to convert one of those into an .ico file. I'd leave it in that graphics directory.

I will give it a try, thanks for the pointers.

> You can add build dependencies to rclone by adding them here - so you'd add goversioninfo here.

The josephspurrier/goversioninfo repo does not publish releases, so it must be built from source.  It is not a proper go module, so I get some issues. Tried adding it with a go install line like this, which sort of works locally, but the "modules_race" test fails with "inconsistent vendoring" (see #4305):
```
# Get the build dependencies
build_dep:
	go run bin/get-github-release.go -extract golangci-lint golangci/golangci-lint 'golangci-lint-.*\.tar\.gz'
	go install -mod=mod github.com/josephspurrier/goversioninfo/cmd/goversioninfo
```

> I will give it a try, thanks for the pointers.
> 
> > You can add build dependencies to rclone by adding them here - so you'd add goversioninfo here.
> 
> The josephspurrier/goversioninfo repo does not publish releases, so it must be built from source. It is not a proper go module, so I get some issues. Tried adding it with a go install line like this, which sort of works locally, but the "modules_race" test fails with "inconsistent vendoring" (see #4305):
> 
> ```
> # Get the build dependencies
> build_dep:
> 	go run bin/get-github-release.go -extract golangci-lint golangci/golangci-lint 'golangci-lint-.*\.tar\.gz'
> 	go install -mod=mod github.com/josephspurrier/goversioninfo/cmd/goversioninfo
> ```

Here is a hacky workaround

    cd .. && go install -mod=mod github.com/josephspurrier/goversioninfo/cmd/goversioninfo

I don't know the proper way of doing this!

I'll probably just use that then.
(There is a pull request https://github.com/josephspurrier/goversioninfo/pull/35 from september 2019 to add go.mod, maybe that will make it easier to use, but I'm not that familiar with go modules myself).

issue.title: Add file properties to rclone executable for windows (fixes #4304)

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
<!--
Thank you very much for contributing code or documentation to rclone! Please
fill out the following questions to make it easier for us to review your
changes.

You do not need to check all the boxes below all at once, feel free to take
your time and add more commits. If you're done and ready for review, please
check the last box.
-->

#### What is the purpose of this change?

<!--
Describe the changes here
-->

Make rclone.exe on windows include file properties such as product name, file description, version, as well as an icon.

The most useful would be the version information, then one could use PowerShell to retrieve the numerical version number `(Get-Item rclone.exe).VersionInfo.FileVersion`, and for instance compare it with latest released version by accessing GitHub API. I know I can execute `rclone version`, but then I need to perform string parsing and also I need to run a process instead of just accessing file properties.

#### Was the change discussed in an issue or in the forum before?

See issue https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/4304.

<!--
Link issues and relevant forum posts here.
-->

#### Checklist

- [X] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-a-pull-request).
- [X] ~I have added tests for all changes in this PR if appropriate.~
- [X] ~I have added documentation for the changes if appropriate.~
- [X] All commit messages are in [house style](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit-messages).
- [x] I'm done, this Pull Request is ready for review :-)

body:
I finally got this working - what a voyage!

Here are the two commits which fixed it

33c8709439ed54779ada79910a9432d509ddeea6
a1c9612d75af9c4caa922e80c423033c3af4dc8d

In 15 mins from now the beta should have nice images and version info :-)

Great!! I checked the latest beta right now, and it works:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12441419/85051716-24470180-b198-11ea-92bc-2c88d78437f2.png)
(Windows shows in its properties dialog "Product version" as the string variant ("1.52.1-094-g40611fc4-beta") and "File version" as the raw 4 part numeric variant (1.52.1.0), while PowerShell shows all 4 version variants).

PS: Sorry I did not manage to clean out those bugs before pushing my merge request, and that it turned out to be such a hard nut. Thank you for working it out!
